title: ISSCC 2019: Deep Learning Hardware: Past, Present, and Future - Yann LeCun
description:
Yann LeCun, Facebook AI Research & New York University, New York, NY

Deep learning has caused revolutions in computer understanding of images, audio, and text,
enabling new applications such as information search and filtering, autonomous driving,
radiology screening, real-time language translation, and virtual assistants. But almost all these
successes largely use supervised learning, which requires human-annotated data, or
reinforcement learning, which requires too many trials to be practical in most real-world
situations. In contrast, animals and humans seem to learn vast amounts of background
knowledge about the world through mere observation and occasional actions in a selfsupervised manner. Making progress in self-supervised learning is the main challenge of AI
for the next decade. Success may result in machines with some level of common sense. But
they will be built around deep learning architectures that are considerably larger than current
ones, requiring vastly more powerful hardware than what we have today.
author: ISSCC Videos

transcript.text: Thank you, Eugenio. A real pleasure to be here. I was reflecting on the fact that I'm seeing a lot of old friends here from Bell Labs that I haven't seen in a long time, like Brian Ackland. And I haven't been to IACCC in about 30 years. I used to be a chief designer, but I'm a little out of date to some extent, but hopefully not too much. So, you know, of course, machine learning and AI is in the news. It's become very important over the last few years. A lot of the big companies are now built around AI and deep learning in particular. And the topic, of course, has piqued the interest of this community for a while. In fact, for a very long time. In fact, you could say that to some extent, the history of AI is intimately linked with the history of hardware development. But what AI is today really is supervised learning. So it's a particular mode of, you know, paradigm, a training paradigm for machines that consists in showing examples to a parameterized function of what we want it to do and then giving it the correct answer. And then, you know, letting it adjust its parameters so that the answer gets closer to the one we want. And by training such machines with generally millions or tens of millions or hundreds of millions of parameters, we can get them to do whatever function we want, like recognizing objects and images. This works amazingly well for speech recognition, image recognition, generating captions for images, translating languages into one another, classifying text, et cetera. But it's a very sort of specific form of learning, which, you know, isn't really what's going to take us, at least not by itself, to truly intelligent machines. If we go back to the history of neural nets in particular, you know, this goes back to the 1940s and 50s, in particular the 1950s with the perceptron, which, of course, was a hardware piece. It was an analog computer where the weights, the adjustable weights of the neural nets were implemented by potentiometers with motors on them. So learning consisted in, you know, pressing a button and having motors turn. There were also competing implementations like Bernie Woodrow's analog system that used electrochemical cells. So what happened then was the creation of the standard paradigm for pattern recognition that survived until fairly recently. In fact, it's still very widely used where you take a signal, let's say an image, and you have some hand-engineered module that turns this image into what's called a feature vector, basically a big vector that you feed to a trainable classifier, and only the classifier is trainable. Now, in modern times, neural nets have kind of changed this model a little bit. And there were some limitations to this model, and basically people abandoned the idea that this model could be used for really sort of making progress towards AI. It was, of course, very successful for pattern recognition. So that kind of caused a sort of neural net winter to appear from the late 60s to the mid-80s, roughly. And one reason is hardware reasons. In fact, it's because people had the wrong neurons. The neurons that people were using at the time were binary neurons, and it kind of stopped people from thinking about things like using gradient descent in multilayer systems because you can't backpropagate gradient through binary neurons. And so it's only in the early 80s when workstations with decent floating-point performance started to appear that people started to think that it was reasonable to actually do floating-point multiplication thousands of times or even tens of thousands of times in a neural net. And that's when backpropagation, the idea that you can train multilayer systems with gradient descent, appeared. So to some extent, that was triggered by progress in the available hardware. So what happened then is the idea that you can essentially stack multiple modules, each of which is trainable, and then train them end-to-end using a gradient descent-based method. So what you put in those boxes are, in fact, very simple functions to implement from the hardware point of view. Things like multiplying a vector by a matrix and then passing all the components of the output vector by a point-wise nonlinearity, as simple as a half-wave rectifier. When I talk to computer scientists, I have to say what a half-wave rectifier is, but in this room, I don't need to explain. So you stack linear operators, matrix multiplication, with point-wise nonlinearity. You can prove that with only two layers of those, you can approximate any function you want. But of course, there is an advantage in stacking multiple layers, and you get more powerful representation of functions that way. So that's the idea of deep learning and neural nets, really. And you can train this using gradient descent. You minimize some sort of objective function with respect to all the parameters in your system. In the case of supervised learning, it measures the discrepancy between the output you want and the output you get, using all types of fancy stochastic optimization methods. And to compute the gradient, you use what's called a backpropagation algorithm, which consists in basically running the circuit backwards, and a slightly modified version of the circuit backwards to kind of propagate gradients. It's basically a practical application of chain rules, so there's nothing really complicated in terms of mathematics there. And the idea has been around since the 60s, but for machine learning only since the mid-80s, roughly. So I joined Bell Labs in 1988, and the group I joined, which was led by Larry Jekyll at the time, was actually focusing on building devices for neural nets. And they started by building, this was before I joined, by building a resistor array, essentially using e-beam lithography. So they could build incredibly small resistor arrays for the time, and then realize, of course, the amplifiers you have to put at the end of it are not that small. And so the advantage of making small resistor arrays was not that great, and so they were not programmable. So the second generation chip was sort of mixed analog-digital, where the input-output were digital, but the competition inside was analog. And the weights were ternary, and you could sort of combine multiple rows in one of those things to kind of get a little bit of bit depth for the competition. The last chip, or the second last chip, I should say, that I kind of participated in, in this one, was the ANA chip, which was actually presented at ISCC in 1991, I believe. And that means analog neural net accelerator. And so it used about six-bit resolution on the weights, about three bits on the activations of the neurons, and it had 64 neurons with 64 input each, with shift registers so that it could do multiple convolutions efficiently. This was a convolutional net accelerator chip, already in 1991. The project was actually started in 1989, roughly. This was capable of four billion operations per second, which at the time was completely unheard of. This was successful in the sense that technically we could run character recognizers at 10,000 recognitions per second, but it wasn't a commercial success in the sense that nobody actually wanted to use it. By the time it was all put in a card and everything, people lost interest in neural nets. So a convolutional net is a particular architecture, a particular way of connecting neurons in a neural net in such a way that you don't have to basically use a full matrix to multiply the input vector. So imagine you have an image. It's represented as an array of pixels, and you basically run a convolution operation, discrete convolution operation, on this, where the coefficients of the filter are learned as part of the backpropagation process. So you don't design the filters. You just let the gradient descent algorithm figure out what the right filters are. And there are several layers in your convolutional net, banks of filters, followed by nonlinearity, followed by a pooling operation, which is basically just a max or an average of the response of the filters in a region. And the purpose of this is to build a little bit of shifting variance in the representation. This is very much inspired by classic neuroscience work from the 60s. So this is a video, actually. This is a younger version of myself here from 1992. And this is actually my phone number at Bell Labs, Homdell, no longer operating. I hit a key, and there's a video camera that grabs the thing and then recognizes the characters. And it can do this at a few tens of characters per second. It's actually running on the DSP32C, which was one of the first floating-point DSPs that at the time was manufactured by AT&T, just in a card stuck in a PC. So this could work pretty well. And this is sort of an example of how those things at the time were working. The internal representation that is learned by the system is hierarchical because of the multiple layers. And what you get inside is sort of some sort of abstract representation that is more and more abstract as you go up the layers. That kind of represents the character, but it learns to really extract the appropriate features for the characters. And we then realized we could use those systems not just to recognize single objects, but multiple objects, without having to explicitly segment the objects from the others beforehand. And that's very important if you want to be able to detect objects in natural images, for example, or separate characters from a cursive word. Eventually, we put this together into a big system that could recognize bank checks. And this was deployed pretty widely by NCR, which at the time was a subsidiary of AT&T. And by the end of the 90s, the system was reading around between 10 and 20 percent of all the checks in the U.S. So it was a big success, scientific, technological, and commercial. And the very same day that we were celebrating the release of the system, AT&T announced that it was breaking itself up, and the department was essentially disbanded. It's typical. Okay. So what happened in the mid-90s is that there was, for some reason, that sociologists of science had to explain, it was the second neural net winter. People in the machine learning community lost interest in those methods in the 90s. And I think it's very interesting. So this is about the same time that we were releasing those systems. And it's interesting to understand why. Hardware was slow for floating point computation. And so the size of the neural net you could train was relatively restricted, and it would take two weeks typically for a practical neural net to be trained. Data was scarce, and neural nets were data hungry. So there were only a few applications for which you could collect economically feasible collection of data. It was only possible for a very small number of applications like character recognition, speech recognition. This was before the internet. There was no flood of data as we have today. Interactive software tools to kind of do those things had to be built from scratch. There was no Python. There was no MATLAB. There was no such thing. You had to kind of build your own thing. So we actually ended up writing our own Lisp interpreter and compiler hooked up to kind of a neural net library, if you want. This is kind of the predecessor of all the modern software frameworks for deep learning. And open sourcing was not common in the pre-internet days. So it wasn't very easy to kind of communicate all the black magic and underlying knowledge that are necessary to make those things work. So a lot of people would try neural nets and couldn't make it work and sort of concluded it didn't work. So that created the winter, which was to last for another 10 years. So one lesson also that we learned from our experience at Bell Labs is that it's hard to succeed with exotic hardware. In fact, the progress of the chips that we built went from hardwired analog to programmable hybrid analog digital to completely digital. I didn't mention that chip, but it was eventually designed. Hardware limitations influenced research direction. Computer scientists like to think that they think in the abstract and hope that the hardware will eventually support their ideas. But in fact, we actually are thinking is limited by the hardware we have at our disposal. So whatever you guys are designing for the next decade will influence AI research. And so it's very important to build the right thing. And that's the topic of the rest of my talk pretty much. Good software tools shape research and give superpowers. And hardware performance, of course, matters for kind of R&D where you need to fasten around to do experimentation. So when hardware is too slow, software is not really available or experiments are not easily reproducible. Good ideas can be abandoned. Neural nets were a good idea, but they were abandoned for about 10 years, if not more. So then the second wave, there was a spring around 2006, if you want. And what happened is a few of us got together and decided we knew those neural nets were a good idea. And we tried to kind of revive the interests of the community in it deliberately. I call this the deep learning conspiracy. And it was composed of myself, Jeffrey Hinton at University of Toronto and Yosha Benjio at University of Montreal. And we kind of got together and deliberately tried to kind of rekindle the interests of the community in those methods. Meanwhile, I thought neural nets could be used for practical applications like driving robots around. So this is a project, a DAPA project that I worked on between 2005 and 2009 that consisted in using a convolutional net to do what's called semantic segmentation. So by kind of sliding a window, a view of a convolutional net over a window and asking it to classify every pixel in an image, as to, in this case, as to whether this pixel corresponds to kind of the ground, whether a robot can drive or an obstacle, you can basically build a map, which is represented here on the top, and then kind of do some planning in this map, and then get a robot to drive around while avoiding obstacles. So this was quite interesting and successful and fun to work on. And this is very similar to some techniques that are used today by autonomous driving systems that are kind of trained to drive cars and sort of detecting obstacles, figuring out where the region of the street is drivable, and sort of avoid annoying pedestrians that jump in front of it, for example. Grad students in this case, who wrote the code and trained the networks, so they're pretty confident the robot is not going to run them over. So soon we realized that we could use the same technique to do sort of more sophisticated semantic segmentation, which means labeling every pixel in an image with the category of the object it belongs to. A few datasets with a few thousand images started popping up, and so we built a system based on convolutional nets that could do this, and we even designed an architecture that we run on an FTGA to run this in real time at about 20 frames per second at 320 by 240 resolution, roughly. That was called the new flow architecture. Some of you may have heard of this. Mostly designed by Clément Farabay, who was a PhD student in my lab at the time. We beat the records here in a number of datasets and sent a paper to a major computer vision conference, and the paper was rejected despite the fact that the system had better performance in accuracy and was about 50 times faster than the best runner-up, even implemented in software, not talking about hardware. And the reason was, you know, most reviewers had never heard of convolutional nets, and they could not believe that a method they'd never heard of could work so well. Now, the thing is, this was 2011. Nowadays you cannot actually get a paper accepted at CVPR, the same conference, unless you use convolutional nets. So that tells you something about the revolution. This is the new flow architecture that I was just mentioning. So this was done over two or three years, between 2009 and 2008 and 2011, and it exploits the structure of convolutions in a big way, so to try to minimize the memory traffic and sort of do a lot, you know, as many operations in succession as possible without going back to memory. So this uses a dataflow architecture, kind of reviving old ideas in architecture from the 1970s. Eventually we collaborated with Eugenio Curuciello's lab at Purdue and got a design for a chip, which was never properly fabricated, so it couldn't be tested. So those ideas kind of are, you know, partly what sort of influenced some of the people working on autonomous driving now, using also semantics segmentation in real time for that purpose. Okay, so the deep learning revolution really occurred around 2012. It occurred a little earlier in speech recognition, but in computer vision it occurred around 2012, 2013, when our colleagues at the University of Toronto in Jeff Hinton's lab used a very efficient GPU implementation on the NVIDIA GPUs at the time of convolutional nets that allowed them to train a very large convolutional net with one billion connections, essentially, and beat the record on the ImageNet dataset, which was sort of a standard benchmark for computer vision. And that really was a watershed moment because the computer vision community basically switched from doing whatever it was that they were doing to using convolutional nets. And since then we've seen a huge progress in reduction in error rate on this particular dataset to the point now that the error rate is so low that, you know, it's below human performance, so I mean it's above human performance, and so it's not an interesting dataset anymore. Simultaneously, the number of layers of those networks kind of ballooned, and a typical neural net used in production today has something like 50 layers. And so that's one of the big kind of changes in architectures that occurred over the last few years, the fact that neural nets are now very deep, relatively large, but there's a lot of work to optimize their memory footprint as well as the number, the amount of computation that they require. So a typical image recognition neural net today, trying to recognize sort of generic objects, requires about 10 billion operations for a single propagation and occupies, you know, on the order of between 50 and 100 megabytes in terms of memory, depending on the resolution you use on the weights. So that is assuming, I suppose, four bytes. So this is kind of an important question here because companies like Facebook, Google, and others use those convolutional nets very, very widely to do content filtering and content ranking. And so every time someone uploads a photo on Facebook, and this happens several billion times a day, this photo goes through a handful of convolutional nets that performed various tasks for detecting objectionable content, performing face recognition, generating descriptions for the visually impaired, and things like that. So a significant amount of computation is devoted to doing those things. And this is going to increase as we scale up this type of content filtering to live video and upload a video where you want to generate subtitles in real time, perhaps translate the language in real time, things like that. So that's going to put a lot of burden on the hardware there. And this community creates demand for work from you guys. So computer vision has done a lot of progress in the last few years. Neural nets that I use now are quite large. And they can do things like, without going into details of architectures, they can do things like not only identify objects but also draw the outline of the objects and if there are human bodies to actually figure out the pose of those objects. So you can count sheep with them or you can sort of estimate the pose of human bodies. This is actually a demo that is lifted off of an iPhone. So this is a real time body pose estimator running on an iPhone at 20 frames per second or so. And this is all open source. So Facebook distributes all that stuff in open source. You can play with it. Of course, there's a lot of applications of this to medical imaging. And it's one of the hottest topics right now in radiology, which is how you can use deep learning for medical imaging. And I see a lot of opportunities there also for hardware acceleration, certainly. So applications in transportation, in health, health care, in science. A lot of neural nets are used for physics, for example, analyzing high energy physics results. Okay, what did we learn from this experience? Good results are not enough. Making them easy reproducible also makes them credible. So you can have good results, but if you can't allow people to reproduce them, they won't believe them. Hardware progress enables new breakthroughs. General purpose GPU should have come 10 years earlier. Sorry, Nvidia. You know, you did a good job. And in fact, it did to some extent, people at Microsoft, Patricia Mott's group in Microsoft, actually started experimenting with GPUs for neural nets back in the mid 2000s. But nobody was interested really back then. But if I have one message for kind of the kind of hardware we require today that is different from what we currently have, is better support for convolutions because there are regularities in convolutions that really, I think, aren't exploited unless I'm mistaken. And hardware that does not require batching. So there is something now you have to run. You want to run a neural net on the GPU and you want to saturate it. What you have to do is wait for 100 or so images to show up. And then you run 100 copies of the same neural net in parallel. That makes the parallelization easy and it makes the low level operation you need to rely on a matrix multiplication. And unfortunately, that is going away. A lot of new neural nets that are coming up are not going to be like that. Open source platforms disseminate ideas. And convolutional nets will soon be everywhere. Hardware that is very low cost, very low power hardware that you can put into cars, cameras, vacuum cleaners, augmented reality glasses, lawnmowers, toys, maintenance robots, whatever. Those things are going to pop up. Of course, smartphone is a big application. Okay. So what about new architectures? Those are going to break the assumptions that current hardware makes. And there are four types really. Memory augmented networks, dynamic networks, graph convolutional nets, and networks with sparse activation. So memory augmented networks is the idea that if you want a machine to reason, not just perceive, you kind of have to give it a sort of working memory if you want. Some sort of associative memory. And so you have a recurrent neural net, a neural net with loops that can sort of iterate multiple times. And it can access a memory. And that memory is basically a soft RAM chip. I'm not going to go into the details of this, but essentially you feed it an address, which is a vector. This address is compared with a bunch of keys using a dot product. It's basically a nearest neighbor algorithm if you want. And then this generates coefficients that you use to compute a linear combination of values. So think of it as kind of a RAM circuit where all the games have been turned down so everything is soft. And the reason you need it to be soft is because you want to be able to back propagate gradient through it. This model actually is used very widely nowadays in things like memory network, transformer networks, things like BERT, which is a very successful architecture for natural language processing. Second problem, the fact that neural nets are becoming dynamic. So instead of a neural net having a fixed architecture, what happens now is that you basically write a program where each call is a call to a module that calls a neural net. And the program has conditionals and loops in it. So in fact, the architecture of the neural net varies in a data-dependent way. And that completely breaks a lot of assumptions we can make about how we parallelize those things on hardware. So here's an example. This is work from physical care research in Menlo Park. You have a picture here at the bottom left. And you also show a sentence in the system that says there is a shiny object that is right of the great metallic cylinder. Does it have the same size as the large rubber sphere? Yourself, if you have to answer that question, you have to go back to the image and then configure your visual system to kind of detect the right things, right? That's exactly what this neural net is doing. It's not actually computing the answer. It's computing the architecture of another neural net that will compute the answer. So the architecture of that second neural net is dynamic. It changes in a data-dependent fashion. And that's the future. A lot of neural nets are going to be that way. And that has led people to kind of think about how we're going to write software in the future, perhaps software 2.0, where a program is really kind of a dynamically generated graph of computation and the function calls are really calls to a parameterizable module whose function is finalized by training. That may be the future of software. Third category, graph convolutional nets or graph neural nets. So those are neural nets of a new type. It's spawning a new subfield, actually, where the input of a neural net is not a tensor. It's not a multidimensional array. It's a function on a graph. And the graph can change structure at every new data point. And so again, there, the neural net is dynamic. It depends on the structure. This is very popular for things like analyzing social networks, chemistry, understanding chemistry, figuring out how to go from one molecule to another, where the two molecules will stick to each other, things like that. So that's very promising. As far as I'm going to skip. So lessons learned. Dynamic networks are gaining popularity for NLP, particularly. Graph scale memory, augmented networks will require efficient associative memory and nearest neighbor engines. Graph conv nets are very promising for many applications. They're still a little bit in the future, but I hope. And perhaps we'll have to say goodbye to matrix multiplication and tensors as the elementary operation there. OK. There's been a lot of things about reinforcement learning. Reinforcement learning really is kind of the way people learn, et cetera. And it works very well for games. But there's a big limitation to reinforcement learning, which is that it requires many, many trials for it to learn anything. If we were to use the kind of standard form of reinforcement learning to train a car to drive itself, it will have to drive millions of hours and cause thousands of accidents, if not tens of thousands, kill many pedestrians before it learns to drive. How is it that humans can learn to drive a car in about 20 hours of training, mostly without crashing? That's a big mystery. And we need to be able to figure this out because we really like to build much more intelligent machines than we can at the moment, things that will allow us to build intelligent personal assistants or even just a robot that has as much common sense as a house cat. Most intelligent machines don't have that now. So how do humans and animals learn? We learn by observation. There's a lot of evidence that we learn a lot about how the world works just by observing. And we like machines to be able to do this as well. And so the future of AI, in my opinion, is this idea of self-supervised learning. We just learn by observing, not by acting, not by being told the name of things, but basically by just figuring out how the world works. And we can do this by training ourselves to predict. So a good example of prediction is let's predict everything that's going to happen in the world, like train a machine to do video prediction, for example, right? Let's predict the next few frames in a video from the past few frames or predict the past from the present. And we can do this very efficiently for text, but not so much for video at the moment. The reason why I'm saying this is because the amount of information that we give to the machine during training at every trial of a machine, we give a very, very small amount of information during reinforcement learning. We only tell the machine whether it did good or bad. For supervised learning, we get a little bit more information. We give it the label or the name of something. We show it. But in self-supervised learning, we're asking the machine to predict everything you can predict from your input that you pretend you don't know. And that's much richer information. So one consequence of this is that the neural nets, once we succeed in doing this, the neural nets we're going to have to train are going to be much, much bigger than the one we currently have. And you guys should smile about this, because this is going to put a lot of demand on the stuff you're building. So the form of self-supervised learning that people use in computer vision consists in doing things like filling in blanks in images or doing video prediction in text, which is one situation where it works great. It consists in showing a piece of text to a machine, blocking some of the words, and asking the machine to basically fill in the blanks in the words. And that leads to machines that can represent text to a surprising degree of accuracy. There's a problem with this, which is that you have to deal with the uncertainty in the world. When you're trying to predict what's going to happen in the video, there are many different futures. And which of the futures are you going to teach the machine to predict? If you show it too many examples, for example, a pen falling on the table, every time the pen falls in a different direction, the best the machine can do if you ask it to make one prediction is predict the average of all the pens that fall in all the directions. You get this kind of transparent pen in all positions. That's not a good thing. So representing uncertainty in a prediction is the big technical challenge that the machine learning community is facing today, in my opinion. The next revolution in AI will not be supervised. You can be sure of that. So how do we learn predictive models? It's very crucial to learn predictive models because that will allow our machines to predict in advance what's going to happen in the world as a consequence of their actions. So, for example, if we have a self-driving car, it might predict in advance. When it turns to the left and there is a cliff, it's going to fall off the cliff and nothing good is going to happen. And you'd like the machine to be able to predict this before actually doing it and prevent itself from doing it. So how do we train machines to have world models that it can use to make predictions in the presence of uncertainty? There's a class of methods called generative adversarial networks that is very promising to do this, which I'm not going to explain, but it basically consists in training two neural nets that was proposed by Ian Goodfellow a few years ago from the University of Montreal. And there's stunning results on this. The faces you see here are not real. These are non-existing people that are produced by essentially drawing a random vector from some distribution, running it through a neural net, and that becomes a picture of a person, of a non-existing person. Here are other examples. This is a project that I've been involved in at Facebook of generating pieces of clothing. We have some data from a famous fashion designer, and we just train one of those generative networks on all the things that they gave us, a few thousand images, and it generates those things. Designers seem to be inspired by it. So our brains are prediction machines, and if we were able to do video prediction, we could do things like, so these are examples of using adversarial networks for video prediction. But if we could do things, we could use this for self-driving cars. We could predict where the cars around us were going to go and perhaps do a good job at avoiding accidents or train ourselves to avoid accidents. This is a project by Camille Coupri and Pauline Luc at Facebook Air Research in Paris. We're not working on self-driving cars, but we're working on prediction. It works pretty well up to about a couple seconds in the future, which is not long enough. Here is another project which I did at NYU under a contract with NVIDIA, actually, who are working on self-driving cars, to also train a self-driving system to predict what the cars around you are going to do. So you are the blue car. There's a bunch of green cars around you. You've been observing them for a while, and you're trying to predict where they're going to go next. So you train a neural net to do this with those techniques that allow this neural net to deal with uncertainty, and you get those kinds of predictions. So on the left, for each of the two blocks here, you have what happens in real life. The second column is what happens if you have a predictive model that doesn't handle uncertainty very well, just predicts one prediction, and the prediction gets blurry after a couple seconds. And then the other two columns are using one of those predictive models where you draw different samples of the latent variables, so you get different predictions. So if you put the system inside of a thing that allows the system to learn to drive, it will actually learn to drive. So you sort of unfold the predictive system, you compute a cost function at every time step, you run this for a couple seconds or something. And this is all in the head of the machine. You don't have to drive an actual car for this. You backpropagate gradient to it and train a neural net to learn to drive, so as to minimize the amount of collisions over the next two seconds. And if you play a few tricks to deal with uncertainty in the system, what you get is something like this. So this is the car driving itself. The little white dot indicates whether the car accelerates or slows down or turns left or right, and it manages to kind of not crash too often. We're not there yet, but making progress. Okay, lesson four, self-supervised learning is the future. Networks would be much larger than today, perhaps have sparse activity. So because they would be very, very large, the best way to represent data in them is to only turn on a small number of neurons. This is a trick that our brains use. Our brains are only about 2% active at any one time, and this is a way to make our brain very power efficient. Power consumption of the brain is about 25 watts for, I don't know, 10 to the 18 operations per second or something like that. So exploiting sparsity is probably something that's coming. Deep learning hardware, there are four use cases for it. High-end deep learning R&D, you need 32-bit floating point, high parallelism, fast internode communication, so you can do massive parallelization, flexible hardware and software. Then you have kind of routine training. Your Facebook, you get new data to train your object recognition system or your translation. You just want to turn the chronic on a standard model. That can be done with 16-bit FP. Of course, you want to parallelize, but not as much as when you are in the R&D loop, and you want the cost to be moderate or at least not outrageous. Then there is inference in data centers, and this is increasingly important because of the prevalence of those applications now for content understanding and filtering. That can work on 8 or 16-bit floating point, low latency, low power consumption, standard interfaces. The last application, which I think has the biggest opportunities for hardware, the hardware community, is inference on embedded devices. They have been very low cost, very low power. Perhaps using exotic number systems have been interesting work at physical care research in that domain, kind of rethinking how you represent floating point numbers with low accuracy. That would be useful for augmented reality, virtual reality, consumer items, household robots, toys, manufacturing systems, etc. My last slide is about speculations. There has been quite a bit of work in the hardware community on neuromorphic architectures, spiking neurons. I am actually very skeptical about this. I would be interested in talking to people about this because I am still very skeptical. And exotic technology, I am interested in learning what some of you have to say about pure analog computations, Pintronics, optical implementations, etc. Thank you very much.

segments.text: Thank you, Eugenio. A real pleasure to be here. I was reflecting on the fact that I'm seeing a lot of old friends here from Bell Labs that I haven't seen in a long time, like Brian Ackland.
And I haven't been to IACCC in about 30 years. I used to be a chief designer, but I'm a little out of date to some extent, but hopefully not too much.

So, you know, of course, machine learning and AI is in the news. It's become very important over the last few years. A lot of the big companies are now built around AI and deep learning in particular.
And the topic, of course, has piqued the interest of this community for a while. In fact, for a very long time.
In fact, you could say that to some extent, the history of AI is intimately linked with the history of hardware development.

But what AI is today really is supervised learning. So it's a particular mode of, you know, paradigm, a training paradigm for machines that consists in showing examples to a parameterized function of what we want it to do and then giving it the correct answer.
And then, you know, letting it adjust its parameters so that the answer gets closer to the one we want.
And by training such machines with generally millions or tens of millions or hundreds of millions of parameters, we can get them to do whatever function we want, like recognizing objects and images.
This works amazingly well for speech recognition, image recognition, generating captions for images, translating languages into one another, classifying text, et cetera.
But it's a very sort of specific form of learning, which, you know, isn't really what's going to take us, at least not by itself, to truly intelligent machines.
If we go back to the history of neural nets in particular, you know, this goes back to the 1940s and 50s, in particular the 1950s with the perceptron, which, of course, was a hardware piece.
It was an analog computer where the weights, the adjustable weights of the neural nets were implemented by potentiometers with motors on them.
So learning consisted in, you know, pressing a button and having motors turn.
There were also competing implementations like Bernie Woodrow's analog system that used electrochemical cells.
So what happened then was the creation of the standard paradigm for pattern recognition that survived until fairly recently.

In fact, it's still very widely used where you take a signal, let's say an image, and you have some hand-engineered module that turns this image into what's called a feature vector, basically a big vector that you feed to a trainable classifier, and only the classifier is trainable.
Now, in modern times, neural nets have kind of changed this model a little bit.
And there were some limitations to this model, and basically people abandoned the idea that this model could be used for really sort of making progress towards AI.
It was, of course, very successful for pattern recognition.
So that kind of caused a sort of neural net winter to appear from the late 60s to the mid-80s, roughly.
And one reason is hardware reasons. In fact, it's because people had the wrong neurons.

The neurons that people were using at the time were binary neurons, and it kind of stopped people from thinking about things like using gradient descent in multilayer systems because you can't backpropagate gradient through binary neurons.

And so it's only in the early 80s when workstations with decent floating-point performance started to appear that people started to think that it was reasonable to actually do floating-point multiplication thousands of times or even tens of thousands of times in a neural net.
And that's when backpropagation, the idea that you can train multilayer systems with gradient descent, appeared.
So to some extent, that was triggered by progress in the available hardware.
So what happened then is the idea that you can essentially stack multiple modules, each of which is trainable, and then train them end-to-end using a gradient descent-based method.
So what you put in those boxes are, in fact, very simple functions to implement from the hardware point of view.
Things like multiplying a vector by a matrix and then passing all the components of the output vector by a point-wise nonlinearity, as simple as a half-wave rectifier.
When I talk to computer scientists, I have to say what a half-wave rectifier is, but in this room, I don't need to explain.
So you stack linear operators, matrix multiplication, with point-wise nonlinearity.
You can prove that with only two layers of those, you can approximate any function you want.
But of course, there is an advantage in stacking multiple layers, and you get more powerful representation of functions that way.
So that's the idea of deep learning and neural nets, really.
And you can train this using gradient descent.
You minimize some sort of objective function with respect to all the parameters in your system.
In the case of supervised learning, it measures the discrepancy between the output you want and the output you get, using all types of fancy stochastic optimization methods.
And to compute the gradient, you use what's called a backpropagation algorithm, which consists in basically running the circuit backwards,
and a slightly modified version of the circuit backwards to kind of propagate gradients.
It's basically a practical application of chain rules, so there's nothing really complicated in terms of mathematics there.
And the idea has been around since the 60s, but for machine learning only since the mid-80s, roughly.
So I joined Bell Labs in 1988, and the group I joined, which was led by Larry Jekyll at the time,
was actually focusing on building devices for neural nets.
And they started by building, this was before I joined, by building a resistor array, essentially using e-beam lithography.
So they could build incredibly small resistor arrays for the time, and then realize, of course, the amplifiers you have to put at the end of it are not that small.
And so the advantage of making small resistor arrays was not that great, and so they were not programmable.
So the second generation chip was sort of mixed analog-digital, where the input-output were digital, but the competition inside was analog.
And the weights were ternary, and you could sort of combine multiple rows in one of those things to kind of get a little bit of bit depth for the competition.
The last chip, or the second last chip, I should say, that I kind of participated in, in this one, was the ANA chip, which was actually presented at ISCC in 1991, I believe.
And that means analog neural net accelerator.
And so it used about six-bit resolution on the weights, about three bits on the activations of the neurons, and it had 64 neurons with 64 input each,
with shift registers so that it could do multiple convolutions efficiently.
This was a convolutional net accelerator chip, already in 1991.
The project was actually started in 1989, roughly.
This was capable of four billion operations per second, which at the time was completely unheard of.
This was successful in the sense that technically we could run character recognizers at 10,000 recognitions per second,
but it wasn't a commercial success in the sense that nobody actually wanted to use it.
By the time it was all put in a card and everything, people lost interest in neural nets.

So a convolutional net is a particular architecture, a particular way of connecting neurons in a neural net in such a way that you don't have to basically use a full matrix to multiply the input vector.
So imagine you have an image. It's represented as an array of pixels, and you basically run a convolution operation, discrete convolution operation,
on this, where the coefficients of the filter are learned as part of the backpropagation process.
So you don't design the filters. You just let the gradient descent algorithm figure out what the right filters are.
And there are several layers in your convolutional net, banks of filters, followed by nonlinearity,
followed by a pooling operation, which is basically just a max or an average of the response of the filters in a region.
And the purpose of this is to build a little bit of shifting variance in the representation.
This is very much inspired by classic neuroscience work from the 60s.
So this is a video, actually. This is a younger version of myself here from 1992.
And this is actually my phone number at Bell Labs, Homdell, no longer operating.
I hit a key, and there's a video camera that grabs the thing and then recognizes the characters.
And it can do this at a few tens of characters per second.
It's actually running on the DSP32C, which was one of the first floating-point DSPs that at the time was manufactured by AT&T, just in a card stuck in a PC.
So this could work pretty well.
And this is sort of an example of how those things at the time were working.
The internal representation that is learned by the system is hierarchical because of the multiple layers.
And what you get inside is sort of some sort of abstract representation that is more and more abstract as you go up the layers.
That kind of represents the character, but it learns to really extract the appropriate features for the characters.
And we then realized we could use those systems not just to recognize single objects, but multiple objects,
without having to explicitly segment the objects from the others beforehand.
And that's very important if you want to be able to detect objects in natural images, for example, or separate characters from a cursive word.
Eventually, we put this together into a big system that could recognize bank checks.
And this was deployed pretty widely by NCR, which at the time was a subsidiary of AT&T.
And by the end of the 90s, the system was reading around between 10 and 20 percent of all the checks in the U.S.
So it was a big success, scientific, technological, and commercial.
And the very same day that we were celebrating the release of the system, AT&T announced that it was breaking itself up,
and the department was essentially disbanded.
It's typical. Okay. So what happened in the mid-90s is that there was, for some reason, that sociologists of science had to explain,
it was the second neural net winter.
People in the machine learning community lost interest in those methods in the 90s.
And I think it's very interesting. So this is about the same time that we were releasing those systems.
And it's interesting to understand why.
Hardware was slow for floating point computation.
And so the size of the neural net you could train was relatively restricted,
and it would take two weeks typically for a practical neural net to be trained.
Data was scarce, and neural nets were data hungry.
So there were only a few applications for which you could collect economically feasible collection of data.
It was only possible for a very small number of applications like character recognition, speech recognition.
This was before the internet.
There was no flood of data as we have today.
Interactive software tools to kind of do those things had to be built from scratch.
There was no Python. There was no MATLAB. There was no such thing.
You had to kind of build your own thing.
So we actually ended up writing our own Lisp interpreter and compiler hooked up to kind of a neural net library, if you want.
This is kind of the predecessor of all the modern software frameworks for deep learning.
And open sourcing was not common in the pre-internet days.
So it wasn't very easy to kind of communicate all the black magic and underlying knowledge that are necessary to make those things work.
So a lot of people would try neural nets and couldn't make it work and sort of concluded it didn't work.
So that created the winter, which was to last for another 10 years.
So one lesson also that we learned from our experience at Bell Labs is that it's hard to succeed with exotic hardware.
In fact, the progress of the chips that we built went from hardwired analog to programmable hybrid analog digital to completely digital.
I didn't mention that chip, but it was eventually designed.
Hardware limitations influenced research direction.
Computer scientists like to think that they think in the abstract and hope that the hardware will eventually support their ideas.
But in fact, we actually are thinking is limited by the hardware we have at our disposal.
So whatever you guys are designing for the next decade will influence AI research.
And so it's very important to build the right thing.
And that's the topic of the rest of my talk pretty much.
Good software tools shape research and give superpowers.
And hardware performance, of course, matters for kind of R&D where you need to fasten around to do experimentation.
So when hardware is too slow, software is not really available or experiments are not easily reproducible.
Good ideas can be abandoned.
Neural nets were a good idea, but they were abandoned for about 10 years, if not more.
So then the second wave, there was a spring around 2006, if you want.
And what happened is a few of us got together and decided we knew those neural nets were a good idea.
And we tried to kind of revive the interests of the community in it deliberately.
I call this the deep learning conspiracy.
And it was composed of myself, Jeffrey Hinton at University of Toronto and Yosha Benjio at University of Montreal.
And we kind of got together and deliberately tried to kind of rekindle the interests of the community in those methods.
Meanwhile, I thought neural nets could be used for practical applications like driving robots around.
So this is a project, a DAPA project that I worked on between 2005 and 2009 that consisted in using a convolutional net to do what's called semantic segmentation.
So by kind of sliding a window, a view of a convolutional net over a window and asking it to classify every pixel in an image,
as to, in this case, as to whether this pixel corresponds to kind of the ground, whether a robot can drive or an obstacle,
you can basically build a map, which is represented here on the top, and then kind of do some planning in this map,
and then get a robot to drive around while avoiding obstacles.
So this was quite interesting and successful and fun to work on.
And this is very similar to some techniques that are used today by autonomous driving systems that are kind of trained to drive cars
and sort of detecting obstacles, figuring out where the region of the street is drivable,
and sort of avoid annoying pedestrians that jump in front of it, for example.
Grad students in this case, who wrote the code and trained the networks, so they're pretty confident the robot is not going to run them over.
So soon we realized that we could use the same technique to do sort of more sophisticated semantic segmentation,
which means labeling every pixel in an image with the category of the object it belongs to.
A few datasets with a few thousand images started popping up, and so we built a system based on convolutional nets that could do this,
and we even designed an architecture that we run on an FTGA to run this in real time at about 20 frames per second at 320 by 240 resolution, roughly.
That was called the new flow architecture. Some of you may have heard of this.
Mostly designed by Clément Farabay, who was a PhD student in my lab at the time.
We beat the records here in a number of datasets and sent a paper to a major computer vision conference,
and the paper was rejected despite the fact that the system had better performance in accuracy
and was about 50 times faster than the best runner-up, even implemented in software, not talking about hardware.
And the reason was, you know, most reviewers had never heard of convolutional nets,
and they could not believe that a method they'd never heard of could work so well.
Now, the thing is, this was 2011. Nowadays you cannot actually get a paper accepted at CVPR, the same conference, unless you use convolutional nets.
So that tells you something about the revolution.
This is the new flow architecture that I was just mentioning.
So this was done over two or three years, between 2009 and 2008 and 2011,
and it exploits the structure of convolutions in a big way, so to try to minimize the memory traffic
and sort of do a lot, you know, as many operations in succession as possible without going back to memory.
So this uses a dataflow architecture, kind of reviving old ideas in architecture from the 1970s.
Eventually we collaborated with Eugenio Curuciello's lab at Purdue and got a design for a chip,
which was never properly fabricated, so it couldn't be tested.
So those ideas kind of are, you know, partly what sort of influenced some of the people working on autonomous driving now,
using also semantics segmentation in real time for that purpose.
Okay, so the deep learning revolution really occurred around 2012.
It occurred a little earlier in speech recognition, but in computer vision it occurred around 2012, 2013,
when our colleagues at the University of Toronto in Jeff Hinton's lab used a very efficient GPU implementation
on the NVIDIA GPUs at the time of convolutional nets that allowed them to train a very large convolutional net
with one billion connections, essentially, and beat the record on the ImageNet dataset,
which was sort of a standard benchmark for computer vision.
And that really was a watershed moment because the computer vision community basically switched from
doing whatever it was that they were doing to using convolutional nets.
And since then we've seen a huge progress in reduction in error rate on this particular dataset
to the point now that the error rate is so low that, you know, it's below human performance,
so I mean it's above human performance, and so it's not an interesting dataset anymore.
Simultaneously, the number of layers of those networks kind of ballooned,
and a typical neural net used in production today has something like 50 layers.
And so that's one of the big kind of changes in architectures that occurred over the last few years,
the fact that neural nets are now very deep, relatively large,
but there's a lot of work to optimize their memory footprint as well as the number, the amount of computation that they require.
So a typical image recognition neural net today, trying to recognize sort of generic objects,
requires about 10 billion operations for a single propagation and occupies, you know,
on the order of between 50 and 100 megabytes in terms of memory, depending on the resolution you use on the weights.
So that is assuming, I suppose, four bytes.
So this is kind of an important question here because companies like Facebook, Google, and others
use those convolutional nets very, very widely to do content filtering and content ranking.
And so every time someone uploads a photo on Facebook, and this happens several billion times a day,
this photo goes through a handful of convolutional nets that performed various tasks for detecting objectionable content,
performing face recognition, generating descriptions for the visually impaired, and things like that.
So a significant amount of computation is devoted to doing those things.
And this is going to increase as we scale up this type of content filtering to live video and upload a video
where you want to generate subtitles in real time, perhaps translate the language in real time, things like that.
So that's going to put a lot of burden on the hardware there.
And this community creates demand for work from you guys.
So computer vision has done a lot of progress in the last few years.
Neural nets that I use now are quite large.
And they can do things like, without going into details of architectures,
they can do things like not only identify objects but also draw the outline of the objects
and if there are human bodies to actually figure out the pose of those objects.
So you can count sheep with them or you can sort of estimate the pose of human bodies.
This is actually a demo that is lifted off of an iPhone.
So this is a real time body pose estimator running on an iPhone at 20 frames per second or so.
And this is all open source.
So Facebook distributes all that stuff in open source.
You can play with it.
Of course, there's a lot of applications of this to medical imaging.
And it's one of the hottest topics right now in radiology,
which is how you can use deep learning for medical imaging.
And I see a lot of opportunities there also for hardware acceleration, certainly.
So applications in transportation, in health, health care, in science.
A lot of neural nets are used for physics, for example, analyzing high energy physics results.
Okay, what did we learn from this experience?
Good results are not enough.
Making them easy reproducible also makes them credible.
So you can have good results, but if you can't allow people to reproduce them, they won't believe them.
Hardware progress enables new breakthroughs.
General purpose GPU should have come 10 years earlier.
Sorry, Nvidia.
You know, you did a good job.
And in fact, it did to some extent, people at Microsoft, Patricia Mott's group in Microsoft,
actually started experimenting with GPUs for neural nets back in the mid 2000s.
But nobody was interested really back then.
But if I have one message for kind of the kind of hardware we require today that is different from what we currently have,
is better support for convolutions because there are regularities in convolutions that really, I think, aren't exploited unless I'm mistaken.
And hardware that does not require batching.
So there is something now you have to run.
You want to run a neural net on the GPU and you want to saturate it.
What you have to do is wait for 100 or so images to show up.
And then you run 100 copies of the same neural net in parallel.
That makes the parallelization easy and it makes the low level operation you need to rely on a matrix multiplication.
And unfortunately, that is going away.
A lot of new neural nets that are coming up are not going to be like that.
Open source platforms disseminate ideas.
And convolutional nets will soon be everywhere.
Hardware that is very low cost, very low power hardware that you can put into cars, cameras, vacuum cleaners, augmented reality glasses, lawnmowers, toys, maintenance robots, whatever.
Those things are going to pop up.
Of course, smartphone is a big application.
Okay. So what about new architectures?
Those are going to break the assumptions that current hardware makes.
And there are four types really.
Memory augmented networks, dynamic networks, graph convolutional nets, and networks with sparse activation.
So memory augmented networks is the idea that if you want a machine to reason, not just perceive, you kind of have to give it a sort of working memory if you want.
Some sort of associative memory.
And so you have a recurrent neural net, a neural net with loops that can sort of iterate multiple times.
And it can access a memory.
And that memory is basically a soft RAM chip.
I'm not going to go into the details of this, but essentially you feed it an address, which is a vector.
This address is compared with a bunch of keys using a dot product.
It's basically a nearest neighbor algorithm if you want.
And then this generates coefficients that you use to compute a linear combination of values.
So think of it as kind of a RAM circuit where all the games have been turned down so everything is soft.
And the reason you need it to be soft is because you want to be able to back propagate gradient through it.
This model actually is used very widely nowadays in things like memory network, transformer networks, things like BERT,
which is a very successful architecture for natural language processing.
Second problem, the fact that neural nets are becoming dynamic.
So instead of a neural net having a fixed architecture, what happens now is that you basically write a program
where each call is a call to a module that calls a neural net.
And the program has conditionals and loops in it.
So in fact, the architecture of the neural net varies in a data-dependent way.
And that completely breaks a lot of assumptions we can make about how we parallelize those things on hardware.
So here's an example. This is work from physical care research in Menlo Park.
You have a picture here at the bottom left.
And you also show a sentence in the system that says there is a shiny object that is right of the great metallic cylinder.
Does it have the same size as the large rubber sphere?
Yourself, if you have to answer that question, you have to go back to the image and then configure your visual system to kind of detect the right things, right?
That's exactly what this neural net is doing. It's not actually computing the answer.
It's computing the architecture of another neural net that will compute the answer.
So the architecture of that second neural net is dynamic. It changes in a data-dependent fashion.
And that's the future. A lot of neural nets are going to be that way.
And that has led people to kind of think about how we're going to write software in the future, perhaps software 2.0,
where a program is really kind of a dynamically generated graph of computation
and the function calls are really calls to a parameterizable module whose function is finalized by training.
That may be the future of software.
Third category, graph convolutional nets or graph neural nets.
So those are neural nets of a new type. It's spawning a new subfield, actually, where the input of a neural net is not a tensor.
It's not a multidimensional array. It's a function on a graph.
And the graph can change structure at every new data point.
And so again, there, the neural net is dynamic. It depends on the structure.
This is very popular for things like analyzing social networks, chemistry, understanding chemistry,
figuring out how to go from one molecule to another, where the two molecules will stick to each other, things like that.
So that's very promising. As far as I'm going to skip.
So lessons learned. Dynamic networks are gaining popularity for NLP, particularly.
Graph scale memory, augmented networks will require efficient associative memory and nearest neighbor engines.
Graph conv nets are very promising for many applications.
They're still a little bit in the future, but I hope.
And perhaps we'll have to say goodbye to matrix multiplication and tensors as the elementary operation there.
OK. There's been a lot of things about reinforcement learning.
Reinforcement learning really is kind of the way people learn, et cetera.
And it works very well for games.
But there's a big limitation to reinforcement learning, which is that it requires many, many trials for it to learn anything.
If we were to use the kind of standard form of reinforcement learning to train a car to drive itself,
it will have to drive millions of hours and cause thousands of accidents, if not tens of thousands,
kill many pedestrians before it learns to drive.
How is it that humans can learn to drive a car in about 20 hours of training, mostly without crashing?
That's a big mystery.
And we need to be able to figure this out because we really like to build much more intelligent machines than we can at the moment,
things that will allow us to build intelligent personal assistants or even just a robot that has as much common sense as a house cat.
Most intelligent machines don't have that now.
So how do humans and animals learn?
We learn by observation.
There's a lot of evidence that we learn a lot about how the world works just by observing.
And we like machines to be able to do this as well.
And so the future of AI, in my opinion, is this idea of self-supervised learning.
We just learn by observing, not by acting, not by being told the name of things, but basically by just figuring out how the world works.
And we can do this by training ourselves to predict.
So a good example of prediction is let's predict everything that's going to happen in the world,
like train a machine to do video prediction, for example, right?
Let's predict the next few frames in a video from the past few frames or predict the past from the present.
And we can do this very efficiently for text, but not so much for video at the moment.
The reason why I'm saying this is because the amount of information that we give to the machine during training at every trial of a machine,
we give a very, very small amount of information during reinforcement learning.
We only tell the machine whether it did good or bad.
For supervised learning, we get a little bit more information.
We give it the label or the name of something. We show it.
But in self-supervised learning, we're asking the machine to predict everything you can predict from your input that you pretend you don't know.
And that's much richer information.
So one consequence of this is that the neural nets, once we succeed in doing this,
the neural nets we're going to have to train are going to be much, much bigger than the one we currently have.
And you guys should smile about this, because this is going to put a lot of demand on the stuff you're building.
So the form of self-supervised learning that people use in computer vision consists in doing things like filling in blanks in images or doing video prediction in text,
which is one situation where it works great.
It consists in showing a piece of text to a machine, blocking some of the words, and asking the machine to basically fill in the blanks in the words.
And that leads to machines that can represent text to a surprising degree of accuracy.
There's a problem with this, which is that you have to deal with the uncertainty in the world. When you're trying to predict what's going to happen in the video,
there are many different futures. And which of the futures are you going to teach the machine to predict?
If you show it too many examples, for example, a pen falling on the table, every time the pen falls in a different direction,
the best the machine can do if you ask it to make one prediction is predict the average of all the pens that fall in all the directions.
You get this kind of transparent pen in all positions. That's not a good thing.
So representing uncertainty in a prediction is the big technical challenge that the machine learning community is facing today, in my opinion.
The next revolution in AI will not be supervised. You can be sure of that.
So how do we learn predictive models? It's very crucial to learn predictive models because that will allow our machines to predict in advance
what's going to happen in the world as a consequence of their actions.
So, for example, if we have a self-driving car, it might predict in advance.
When it turns to the left and there is a cliff, it's going to fall off the cliff and nothing good is going to happen.
And you'd like the machine to be able to predict this before actually doing it and prevent itself from doing it.
So how do we train machines to have world models that it can use to make predictions in the presence of uncertainty?
There's a class of methods called generative adversarial networks that is very promising to do this, which I'm not going to explain,
but it basically consists in training two neural nets that was proposed by Ian Goodfellow a few years ago from the University of Montreal.
And there's stunning results on this. The faces you see here are not real.
These are non-existing people that are produced by essentially drawing a random vector from some distribution,
running it through a neural net, and that becomes a picture of a person, of a non-existing person.
Here are other examples. This is a project that I've been involved in at Facebook of generating pieces of clothing.
We have some data from a famous fashion designer, and we just train one of those generative networks on all the things that they gave us,
a few thousand images, and it generates those things. Designers seem to be inspired by it.
So our brains are prediction machines, and if we were able to do video prediction, we could do things like,
so these are examples of using adversarial networks for video prediction.
But if we could do things, we could use this for self-driving cars. We could predict where the cars around us were going to go
and perhaps do a good job at avoiding accidents or train ourselves to avoid accidents.
This is a project by Camille Coupri and Pauline Luc at Facebook Air Research in Paris.
We're not working on self-driving cars, but we're working on prediction.
It works pretty well up to about a couple seconds in the future, which is not long enough.
Here is another project which I did at NYU under a contract with NVIDIA, actually, who are working on self-driving cars,
to also train a self-driving system to predict what the cars around you are going to do.
So you are the blue car. There's a bunch of green cars around you. You've been observing them for a while,
and you're trying to predict where they're going to go next.
So you train a neural net to do this with those techniques that allow this neural net to deal with uncertainty,
and you get those kinds of predictions. So on the left, for each of the two blocks here, you have what happens in real life.
The second column is what happens if you have a predictive model that doesn't handle uncertainty very well,
just predicts one prediction, and the prediction gets blurry after a couple seconds.
And then the other two columns are using one of those predictive models where you draw different samples of the latent variables,
so you get different predictions. So if you put the system inside of a thing that allows the system to learn to drive,
it will actually learn to drive. So you sort of unfold the predictive system, you compute a cost function at every time step,
you run this for a couple seconds or something. And this is all in the head of the machine.
You don't have to drive an actual car for this. You backpropagate gradient to it and train a neural net to learn to drive,
so as to minimize the amount of collisions over the next two seconds.
And if you play a few tricks to deal with uncertainty in the system, what you get is something like this.
So this is the car driving itself. The little white dot indicates whether the car accelerates or slows down or turns left or right,
and it manages to kind of not crash too often. We're not there yet, but making progress.
Okay, lesson four, self-supervised learning is the future. Networks would be much larger than today, perhaps have sparse activity.
So because they would be very, very large, the best way to represent data in them is to only turn on a small number of neurons.
This is a trick that our brains use. Our brains are only about 2% active at any one time,
and this is a way to make our brain very power efficient. Power consumption of the brain is about 25 watts for, I don't know,
10 to the 18 operations per second or something like that. So exploiting sparsity is probably something that's coming.
Deep learning hardware, there are four use cases for it. High-end deep learning R&D, you need 32-bit floating point, high parallelism,
fast internode communication, so you can do massive parallelization, flexible hardware and software.
Then you have kind of routine training. Your Facebook, you get new data to train your object recognition system or your translation.
You just want to turn the chronic on a standard model. That can be done with 16-bit FP.
Of course, you want to parallelize, but not as much as when you are in the R&D loop, and you want the cost to be moderate or at least not outrageous.
Then there is inference in data centers, and this is increasingly important because of the prevalence of those applications now for content understanding and filtering.
That can work on 8 or 16-bit floating point, low latency, low power consumption, standard interfaces.
The last application, which I think has the biggest opportunities for hardware, the hardware community, is inference on embedded devices.
They have been very low cost, very low power. Perhaps using exotic number systems have been interesting work at physical care research in that domain,
kind of rethinking how you represent floating point numbers with low accuracy.
That would be useful for augmented reality, virtual reality, consumer items, household robots, toys, manufacturing systems, etc.
My last slide is about speculations. There has been quite a bit of work in the hardware community on neuromorphic architectures, spiking neurons.
